question: Section 202 06 (b)
sols_html:
From part (a) the coefficients of the Fourier series were found to be:

\[\begin{aligned} c_0 &= \frac{1}{2} \\ c_n &= \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } n \text{ is even, } n \not= 0 \\ \frac{-i}{\pi n} & \text{if } n \text{ is odd} \end{cases} \end{aligned}\]

This yields

\[\begin{aligned} f(x)= c_0+\sum_{n \text{ odd, } n=-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{-i}{\pi n} e^{2\pi inx}\end{aligned}\]

Parseval\(^{\prime}\)s Theorem states:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{a}^{b}\left | f(x) \right |^2=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\left | c_n \right |^2\end{aligned}\]

Computing the left side:

\[\begin{aligned} \mathrm{LHS} = \int_{a}^{b}\left | f(x) \right |^2=\int_{0}^{1/2}1^2=\frac{1}{2}\end{aligned}\]

Computing the right side:

\[\begin{aligned} \mathrm{RHS} = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\left | c_n \right |^2=(\frac{1}{2})^2+\sum_{n \text{ odd, } n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\pi ^2n^2}+\sum_{n \text{ odd, } n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\pi ^2(-n)^2}\end{aligned}\]

Here the sum of odds from \(-\infty\) to \(\infty\) was split into two sums from 1 to \(\infty\) and -1 to \(-\infty\). It can be observed that the second sum is the same as the first where \(n=-n\) and since \((-n)^2=n^2\), these two sums are equivalent.

\[\begin{aligned} \mathrm{RHS} = (\frac{1}{2})^2+2(\sum_{n \text{ odd, } n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\pi ^2n^2})\end{aligned}\]

To get the expression that we want we can make a substitution of variables to remove the odd restriction in our sum. Let \(n=2k+1\). It can be seen that for k=0,1,2,3,..., n will always be odd.

Note: Making this substitution will change summation range.

At \(n=1, 1=2k+1 \Rightarrow k=0\). So the new summation range will be \(k=0\) to \(\infty\).

\[\begin{aligned} \mathrm{RHS} =\frac{1}{4}+2(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\pi ^2(2k+1)^2})\end{aligned}\]

Using the left side that was computed above we get:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{4}+\frac{2}{\pi ^2}(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2k+1)^2})\end{aligned}\]

Rearranging this to get the final answer:

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2k+1)^2}=\frac{\pi ^2}{8}\end{aligned}\]
